_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Frozen Fruit, Juice, and Vegetable Manufacturing

_accidents.CI_OtherType: Revised / created in-house procedures and/or checklists; additional RETA training

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The Dole Packaged Foods, Atwater, California site ("Dole Atwater") is strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety. This commitment is demonstrated by Dole Atwater's comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at the Dole site in Atwater, California. It is Dole Atwater's policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances. Dole Atwater is also committed to responding to emergencies resulting from accidental releases in order to mitigate the release and any associated consequences.



Stationary Source and the Regulated Substances Handled

Primary activity at Dole Atwater is processing fresh fruit.  Dole Atwater has one regulated substance, refrigeration grade anhydrous ammonia present at the site.  The anhydrous ammonia is used in two interconnected refrigeration plants to freeze packaged fruit.



The General Accidental Release Prevention Program

The Dole Atwater site has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set out under 40 CFR part 68 of the EPA. The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that is in place at the site.



Process Safety Information

Dole Atwater maintains detailed records of process safety information that describe the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with the refrigeration system. Examples include; Material Safety Data Sheets, piping and instrumentation diagrams (P&ID's), and, equipment specification sheets.



Process Hazard Analysis

Dole Atwater conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with the refrigeration system are identified and effectively controlled. The "what-if checklist" methodology is primarily used to carry ou

t these analyses.  Studies utilize an appropriate team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering, maintenance and process operations and are revalidated on a regular basis. Any findings related to the hazard analysis, where a response is required, are tracked to ensure resolution in a timely and appropriate manner.



Operating Procedures

For the purposes of safely conducting activities within Dole Atwater's refrigeration system, written operating procedures are maintained. These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, and, normal shutdown and startup after a turnaround. The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the process.



Training

Dole Atwater has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating the refrigeration system are competent in the operating procedures and safe work practices associated with this process. Refresher training is provided at least once every 3 years, and more frequently as needed, for required process and safety topics.



Mechanical Integrity

Dole Atwater carries out documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper operations. Process equipment examined by these checks includes among others pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, critical instruments, emergency shutdown systems, controls and pumps. Qualified personnel with previous training in maintenance practices are utilized to carry out appropriate maintenance. These personnel are also offered specialized training as needed. Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.



Management of Change

Written procedures are in place at Dole Atwater to safely manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment and procedures. Process operators, maintenance personne

l or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and offered training to safely work with the modification.



Pre-startup Reviews

Pre-start up safety reviews related to new processes and to modifications in established processes are conducted by appropriate personnel as a regular practice at Dole Atwater. These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.



Compliance Audits

Dole Atwater conducts audits of compliance systems for RMP requirements on a regular basis. These audits are carried out at least once every 3 years by a team of qualified personnel. Any corrective actions required as a result of the audits are tracked to ensure resolution in a timely and appropriate manner.



Incident Investigation

Dole Atwater promptly and carefully investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a release of anhydrous ammonia. These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring. All reports are retained for a minimum of 5 years.



Employee Participation

Dole Atwater truly believes that process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort. Company employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements. The site has safety teams, which involve employees as leaders in facilitating team efforts. In addition, Dole Atwater employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP rule, including information resulting from process hazard analyses in particular. Safe job performance is required for each of the jobs at the site.



Contractors

On occasion, Dole Atwater hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance

, construction and various other activities. Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of safety performance of the contractor is carried out.  Dole Atwater has a policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards related to the contractor's work and the processes. Contractors are also required to inform Dole of any hazards they may introduce at the site. Contractors are also informed of all the procedures for emergency response should an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia occur.



Five-year Accident History

In the last 5 years there has been one accidental release from Dole Atwater that resulted in an off-site impact.  On December 4, 2012, approximately 89 pounds of anhydrous ammonia was released from Plant 2.  Local emergency response and governmental agencies were informed. Dole's hazmat teams made several entries to control the release of ammonia.  There were no reported injuries at the facility or off-site, however several surrounding residential homes were affected.   The local residents were informed about the incident and were given the option of sheltering in place or evacuating and they were able to return home a short time later.  Damage to the facility was minor and only affected a length of pipe and small section of roof over the engine room.



Emergency Response Plan

Dole Atwater utilizes a written emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials. The plan includes all aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, sheltering-in-place, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, as well as post-incident decontamination of affected areas. To ensure proper functioning, Dole Atwater emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced. In addition, the plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place that would require a modified emergency response.  Dole Atwater also coordinates our plans and actions

with local agencies which provide Dole Atwater with additional emergency response capability.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Improving safety is a continuous process at Dole Atwater. PHA's, Compliance Audits, Incident Investigations, Emergency Response Drills and employee participation are a primary means for identifying opportunities to improve safety.

Significant plant improvements during the last 4 years directed towards improving the safety of refrigeration system operations include:

     Installation of equalizing line between condenser and HPR. 

     Installation of the Vacom control system.

     Installation of anhydrous ammonia coil and piping guards. 

     Replacement of IQF3 with new IQF2. 

     Replacement of refrigeration system header in engine room Plant 1. 

     Replacement of puree chiller. 

     Replacement of six refrigeration coils in Consumer Pack. 

     Replacement of two condensers.

     Replacement of Plant 1 intercooler.

Structural seismic upgrades, materials of construction upgrades, installing additional process instrumentation and/or process controls, and conducting Hazard Awareness training are typical of currently planned changes to improve safety at the facility.
